Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies: It is City of Tulsa policy to safeguard the health and welfare of City employees and the general public and to comply with all applicable federal, state, and local laws. The City of Tulsa Safety and Health Manual includes Section 301 Hazard Communication, and Section 310 Emergency Action, both of which are directly applicable to the Risk Management Program. The program includes a Risk Management Plan (RMP) to help ensure ongoing safe practices, and an Emergency Action Plan (EAP). All employees are authorized to call 911 if they feel the situation justifies it.

 

Stationary source and the regulated substances handled: The City of Tulsa owns and operates the Mohawk Water Treatment Plant (WTP), where it stores liquid chlorine under pressure in two 25-ton above-ground storage tanks in bulk quantities not to exceed 40,000 pounds per tank for a total of 80,000 pounds. Chlorine is the primary disinfectant used in the water treatment process.



The two 25-ton storage tanks are located inside the chemical feed building on the west side of the WTP property. The tanks were designed, constructed, tested, and marked in accordance with the ASME Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code, Section VIII, Division 1, Rules for Construction of Pressure Vessels. Chlorine is fed as a gas from the tanks to the chemical treatment stream using vacuum chlorinators that regulate the quantities called for by the plant operation protocols. The room housing the storage tanks is equipped with an air collection system designed to feed a packed tower scrubber to minimize the impact of an accidental release. The scrubber system was designed in accordance with the Uniform Fire Code with a capacity sufficient to treat the entire contents of one 25-ton storage tank. The storage tanks and appurtenant valves and piping are maintained in accordance with Chlorine Institute standards.



General accidental release prevention and chemical-specific preve

ntion steps: The Mohawk WTP operation includes measures to ensure compliance with EPA's Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions (40 CFR Part 68) and all applicable state and local regulations. The chlorine bulk storage tanks, scrubber system, piping, and associated equipment are designed, manufactured, installed, and maintained in accordance with applicable ASME, Chlorine Institute, and Uniform Fire Code Standards. The City of Tulsa has completed a hazard review of the chlorine system and documented the findings. Operations and maintenance procedures have been developed and implemented to ensure proper operation and equipment integrity, and those procedures are updated as needed. All employees responsible for the operation and maintenance of the chlorine system have been trained and participate in regularly scheduled refresher training. Training records are maintained.



Five-year accident history: The Mohawk WTP has had no accidental release during the last 5 years.



The Emergency Response Program: The City of Tulsa has prepared and implemented an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) for chlorine releases and other emergencies at the Mohawk WTP. The purpose of the EAP is to protect employees and the public in the event of an accidental release of chlorine from the facility, and other events that may threaten safety and health, and to provide direction for notifications and evacuation if necessary. There is not a designated HAZMAT team comprised of plant personnel. If Mohawk personnel are unable to contain a minor or incidental chlorine release based on their level of training and the equipment available, outside assistance will be called in through the 911 system, the Tulsa Fire Department's HAZMAT Team, and the chlorine supplier. The responsibilities of each outside agency are provided in the RMP. The Tulsa Area Emergency Management Agency (TAEMA) has included the Mohawk chlorine process in the community emergency response plan. 



Planned changes to improve safety: Co
ntinuing emphasis on safety and improvement are standard operating procedures. New opportunities to promote safety will be evaluated and encouraged.
